protocol.title: Protocol for Differentiation of Blood-Brain Barrier Endothelial Cells from Human Pluripotent Stem Cells
protocol.title_html: Protocol for Differentiation of Blood-Brain Barrier Endothelial Cells from Human Pluripotent Stem Cells

source.description:
On day 0, aspirate E8 medium and add
of E6 per well.

source.body: Note: Cells are seeded for differentiation in E8 medium according to the standardized single cell seeding protocol

source.description:
Change medium every day using
of E6 per well.

At day 4 of E6 treatment, aspirate and add
of EC medium with bFGF (basic fibroblast growth factor) and
RA to each well.

source.body: Medium is NOT changed during expansion phase.

source.description:
BBB subculturing:
On day 6, subculture BBB onto plates and Transwell filters according to the following protocol:
.

source.title: Protocol for Subculture of Differentiated Blood-Brain Barrier Endothelial Cells onto Plates and Filters

materials.name: Gibco™ DPBS no calcium no magnesium

vendor.name: Gibco™ DPBS no calcium no magnesium

description: Human induced pluripotent stem cell (iPSC)-derived developmental lineages are key tools for in vitro mechanistic interrogations, drug discovery, and disease modeling. iPSCs have previously been differentiated to endothelial cells with blood-brain barrier (BBB) properties, as defined by high transendothelial electrical resistance (TEER), low passive permeability, and active transporter functions. Typical protocols use undefined components, which impart unacceptable variability on the differentiation process. We demonstrate that replacement of serum with fully defined components, from common medium supplements to a simple mixture of insulin, transferrin, and selenium, yields BBB endothelium with TEER in the range of 2,000-8,000 Ω × cm2across multiple iPSC lines, with appropriate marker expression and active transporters. The use of a fully defined medium vastly improves the consistency of differentiation, and co-culture of BBB endothelium with iPSC-derived astrocytes produces a robust in vitro neurovascular model. This defined differentiation scheme should broadly enable the use of human BBB endothelium for diverse applications.
